title: Monday, 9th July, 2018

Here's HSBC

Lemmy Man who did nothing resigns.
BE11:15am

The markets have taken the news of Mr Davis’ resignation calmly, with sterling little changed, and the implied probability of an August rate rise from the BoE still at 80%. Indeed, away from politics, the UK has seen some better news of late, with the June PMIs having risen and consumer sentiment buoyed by recent good weather and the continuing success of the England team in the World Cup.
For now, it does not seem that a government fall is imminent. However, there remains a near-term risk of a challenge to Mrs May’s leadership of the Conservative Party. For this to occur, 48 MPs (15% of MPs) would need to submit letters to the 1922 committee of backbench Conservative MPs. There would then be a vote among Conservative MPs. In our view, there might not be enough MPs willing to vote against her, and for the instability that ousting her would entail at this crucial time. Out of 318 MPs, only around 60-80 are thought to be members of the Brexiteer European Research Group.
If Mrs May won such a leadership challenge, then it would in our view increase the chances of her vision of a softer Brexit happening. While the Chequers proposal from last week is not thought to be acceptable to the EU at the moment (see for example, EU diplomats remain guarded over May’s Brexit comprise, Guardian, 7 July 2018), it might form the basis for a deal further down the line.

BE11:16am

The rules of a Conservative Party leadership vote: In the event she lost such a vote, there would be a new leadership contest within the Conservative party, which could in theory take several weeks to conclude. The first stage would be for MPs to put themselves forward. Then there would be a series of votes among parliamentary MPs. In each round, the lowest scoring candidate would be out of the race. When only two remained, these two names would be put to the party membership for a postal vote. This postal vote would be open for several weeks, unless the party decided to unite behind one candidate and the other dropped out. (This was the case in 2016, when Andrea Leadsom dropped out leaving Theresa May as the winner by default). The bookies’ current favourites are, in descending order, Sajid Javid, Michael Gove, Jacob Rees Mogg and Boris Johnson. Even in the event of a change in prime minister, there is no compulsion on the PM to hold an early election. The new leader might well decide to hold fire with so little time to go before Brexit day (29 March 2019).
A bigger escalation would be a vote of no confidence in the government by MPs in parliament as a whole. While Theresa May may have the support of the majority of her party, she only just managed to command a majority in parliament in some of the votes on the amendments to the recent Brexit withdrawal bill. If Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn were to challenge her government to a vote of no confidence, and the Brexiteers angry at her approach were to vote against or abstain, it might be much tighter. There has been no suggestion that Mr Corbyn is gearing up to make such a move, but he did tweet last night that “Theresa May has no authority left and is incapable of delivering Brexit.” If Mrs May lost a government vote of no confidence, she would have two weeks’ grace to make changes and face a second vote. In that time, she might resign, reshuffle her cabinet or enact policy u-turns, in order to avert an election.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

None of which will be news to most people here, I imagine.

Flaneur Baker cites 'crisis in political economy all across Europe' as reason for caution rather then genesis of the whole thing.... cart, horse, etc...
BE11:17am

And Citi. Christian Schulz.

BE11:18am

Even if Davis’ resignation proves to be just another bump on the road towards the smooth Brexit we expect, the next few weeks until parliamentary recess begins on 24 July could be volatile. A wider rebellion, a leadership challenge, early elections and possibly another major shift in the Brexit strategy (either way) cannot be ruled out.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

In our preview of the Chequers cabinet offsite meeting we said that (1) Theresa May’s new third way on Brexit looked increasingly similar to the Swiss model, (2) that it would face the test of cabinet unity, with a couple of resignations probably “priced in” by May, (3) that then the EU would have to engage with it and (4) that negotiating such a bespoke deal would probably take a much longer time than the rest of the Article 50 period and the 21-month transition afford.

squarepeg I see BPC is getting jiggy> Will they finally do a deal?
BE11:19am

On 1) Some watering down of red lines – As expected, the main new element of the government’s Brexit strategy compared to the Mansion House speech was the call for “frictionless access [between the UK and the EU] to each other's markets for goods, including agricultural, food and fisheries products". The UK would accept EU regulations in these fields and UK courts would “pay due regard to the CJEU’s jurisprudence where the UK had chosen to apply a common rulebook to ensure consistent interpretation". A “mobility framework” could replace (but also contain some elements of) free mobility of EU workers. Many questions remain unanswered and the White Paper planned later this week may not address all of them, including whether there will be material new proposals for services trade or customs.

RA hey
BE11:19am

On 2) Will anyone follow Davis? – Initially, all ministers signed up to the plan and Theresa May even restored cabinet discipline on Brexit, meaning ministers may have to resign if they criticise government policy. Davis’ resignation challenges the agreement, but the question will now be whether this turns into a wider rebellion. With the customs bill scheduled to return to Parliament, the government may soon face more crunch votes on its Brexit strategy. May needs the support of almost all of her MPs and the DUP. Under the fixed-term Parliament Act, new elections could only be triggered if government and opposition agree on it (a two-thirds majority in Parliament as in April 2017), or if the government loses a confidence vote and fails to regain it within 14 days.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

However, we probably have enough Brexit clusterflux elsewhere on the site.

BE11:20am

And since it's not (yet) a markets story, let's turn to something that is.

undefined

(@squarepeg: I just rolled my eyes so far back in my head I think I destroyed several childhood memories.)

Okay, so Centamin.

Centamin PLC (CEY:LSE): Last: 111.15, down 6.6 (-5.61%), High: 119.10, Low: 108.35, Volume: 6.78m
Soundbuy He He..........
11:22 am
BE11:22am

....... as requested by someone or other. The news isn't good.

BE11:23am

Q2 production's rubbish. Miss consensus by 15%.

Grouchmonkey Q is whether it is really any worse than the original profits warning
BE11:23am

You'll remember the May warning from Centamin about equipment shortages and stuff, so this isn't that big a surprise.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

And management doesn't change the guidance given in May.

BE11:24am

In spite of that guidance now looking very, very ambitious.

BE11:24am

To recap, Centamin aiming for 505-515koz by full year.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Having just done 92.8koz in Q2, which was down a quarter on Q1.

BE11:25am

Meaning production in the second half needs to be up 35% on the first half.

BE11:26am

Is that likely? Maybe, if equipment shortages ease. But what evidence do we have that that'll happen?

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:27am

We expected a low grade in the open pit, but not in the underground.
Centamin's gold production of 93koz for 2Q was 13% below our estimate of
107koz. This was driven by lower grades at the underground. We had expected low grades at the open pit, which came in line with our estimate of 0.5g/t. However, underground production was impacted by low grades too – we had forecast a grade of 6g/t in 2Q, but the company has reported 4.62g/t, its lowest ever quarter (the company reported an impact from higher dilution in the stopes). This meant that the grade delivered to the mill was just 1.02g/t vs MS 1.21g/t, i.e. 15% below our estimate. This was offset slightly by throughput of 3.172mt, 2% ahead of our estimate.

BE11:27am

Lots to do in 2H, earnings downgrades for Q2 likely. The company needs to produce 293koz in 2H to hit the midpoint of guidance of 505-515koz. That implies production of 147koz per quarter. That has been achieved 3 times before, but it leaves little room for error. We estimate an impact on our Q2 EBITDA of c.$8m or c.13% of our Q2 forecast – consensus production estimates were very close to ours, so we would expect similar movement there.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And BMO

BE11:29am

The company had previously reported weak Q1/18 production and
downgraded full-year guidance on continued issues, so a disappointing result was somewhat anticipated. While management has subsequently observed an improvement in open pit performance and expects a materially stronger H2/18, confidence in medium-term expectations for the underground will need to be gained for credibility to be reestablished.

BE11:30am

Our target price, based on a weighted blend of 1.5x NPV5% and 7.5x CFPS, has been reduced to £1.50 after updating our model. We maintain our Outperform recommendation as current multiples of 1.4x NPV5% and 5.5x CFPS appear in line with peer averages but a forecast dividend yield of 6.2% in 2019 appears relatively attractive.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

And there's not a lot more to say there.

Risks: Operationally, executing on existing contracts in biomass and new customer airlines/routes for Southend are the key issues for these divisions. The progress of the asset realisations are key to the medium-term continuity of the dividend payout. Corporate governance remains in focus but past issues have been addressed.

BE11:46am

BE11:47am

Charles Ergen has shown interest in Inmarsat. We believe his interest goes beyond the strategic fit with Echostar. It includes the benefit for Dish – the sister company of Echostar – of owning the spectrum Inmarsat licenses to Ligado, a competitor it tried to acquire five years ago. In Dish’s Q1 18 conference call, Ergen mentioned that he ‘did not exclude merging Echostar and Dish’. The PUSU rules do not apply to Dish. Inmarsat bid speculation is likely to continue.

SoS I went to Barra airport - walked in and no-one there. Had a look around and was just about to leave money for a lovely piece of cake that was on the shelf when a couple of security people rushed in white faced and said "how did you et here?" through the front door I answered.They chucked us out!
BornCynic SoS - probably because you had eaten their lunch?
11:48 am
BE11:48am

Exane values the Ligado spectrum at 260p per share, with just half of that in its target price of 500p.

alewis2005 I once got thrown out of gatwick by armed police for trying to sleep on some chairs air-side. Apparently that's not allowed, even though I had a ticket to fly within 12 hours of me doing so!
alewis2005 I was a student at the time, if that clears any misconceptions!
BE11:49am

I should also quote RBC, since they write a lot about Inmarsat.

Tom Dalgleish Illegal to fall asleep!
BE11:50am

Echostar's announcement on Friday that it would not be making a formal offer means it is banned from making an offer for six months. For all the reasons mentioned in our previous notes (synergies, operational complementarity, relationship to Ligado, L-band and S-band
spectrum, position in the convertible bond) we continue to believe that
Echostar is still keen to take control of Inmarsat. Although against the spirit of Rule 2.8, it is possible - if Inmarsat is willing - for Echostar and Inmarsat to reach a private deal within the six month period (indeed, Echostar explicitly referenced Note 2 to Rule 2.8 in its statement). However, (1) this route is only open if Inmarsat's board is willing to negotiate (which it may not be), (2) any negotiation would be strictly in private (ie no public comment), (3) the result would have to be a recommended offer. Such a route would be unusual, but interestingly could suit Echostar very well: (a) Inmarsat management will be under pressure to deliver, (b) Echostar can see if any other bidders now step forward (thus gauging how competitive any negotiation should be), (c) we believe Echostar needs Inmarsat's board to recommend an offer in any case, as a hostile approach (which could now only happen in six months time) is likely to be very difficult politically given the protected status of satellite infrastructure.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

Target goes back from 850p to 725p.

BE11:51am

However, to reiterate what we said on Friday, I really can't imagine that the Panel would be happy with any attempts to "reach a private deal" within the six-month block.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Caz says: things could be worse.

BE11:55am

We upgrade TalkTalk to Neutral as we believe the company has reached
the end of its downgrades cycle. The operating picture of the business has
been mostly encouraging and good progress has been made over the
course of FY18, laying the ground for growth from FY19 onwards. The
risk reward is now skewed to the upside. We believe there is meaningful
upside to consensus if Talk delivers in line with its stated ambitions.
Further, the recent stake increases by key shareholders are encouraging. In our recent report Let's Talk we argued that operationally Talk is likely to
surprise on the upside, while the financials still carried some risks. We
believe this has largely played out with the full year results and downside
risks to financial performance are now more limited vs. consensus.
